results.title: Stations of the elevated
results.brief_description: Beginning in the switching yards as they set out on their daily route, Kirchheimer has photographed New Yorks trains as works of art and canvases for the city’s graffiti. As they travel through the decaying urban landscape, they are juxtaposed with advertisements which the filmmaker calls ‘sanctioned vandalism’. Eloquently combines glimpses of faces, billboards and 20th Century artefacts with an urban jazz soundtrack, by Charles Mingus, to create a political film exploring the possibilities of cinema and the visual texture of urban life.

results.title: State opening of Parliament
results.brief_description: The first colored film of the annual ceremonial State Opening of Parliament. The State Drive from Buckingham Palace to Westminster and the assembly of the members of both Houses of Parliament and the heads of foreign missions. The Queen’s speech from the throne, where Her Majesty announces to the assembled Lords and Commons the legislation proposed by Her Ministers for the coming year.

results.title: State of the art. Part 6: Identity
results.brief_description: IDENTITY: The film observes artists in three very different situations. The international art world converges on the 1986 Sydney Biennale. A group of young black artists work on a mural in London.

results.title: State of the art. Part 4: Sexuality
results.brief_description: SEXUALITY: In a consideration of representation and identity, the film explores how artists can create alternatives to the conventional images of women and men in fashion, magazines and the media.

results.title: State of the art. Part 3: Imagination
results.brief_description: IMAGINATION: Investigating the linked themes of work, creativity and imagination, the film explores the creativity with five artists working in distinct and very different ways.

results.title: State of the art. Part 2: Value
results.brief_description: VALUE: On a journey through the art world in Germany and the United States, the film asks two closely related questions. How does a work of art acquire its aesthetic worth - who decided today whether it is good or not? And how does it gain financial worth - who says one canvas is worth more than a fortune and another next to nothing?

results.title: State of the art. Part 1: History
results.brief_description: Beginning in the frenetic, image-swamped ‘post-modern’ world of today, the film examines the work of four artists who look to the past to make sense of the present and the future.
